misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Assumed Automatic Synchronization of Parallel Arrays
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if they sort the scores array, the names array will still line up correctly so that the element at index N-1 in names corresponds to the highest value at index N-1 in scores. In other words, they think the parallel arrays remain correctly paired even when only one of them is sorted.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, Arrays.sort(scores) only permutes the elements of the scores array; it has no knowledge of or effect on the names array. After sorting scores in place, the index positions of scores no longer match the original student order, but names still remain in the original order. To keep parallel arrays aligned, you must either (a) sort indices and use those to access both arrays, (b) perform the same swaps on both arrays during sorting, or (c) encapsulate name and score in a single object and sort a single array of those objects. The student's code assumes that sorting just scores is enough to identify the correct top student by using the same index in names.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: wrong output (the printed name may not be the student who achieved the highest score)

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when sorting one array (`scores`) that is conceptually linked to a parallel array (`names`), the Java runtime environment will automatically reorder the elements in the parallel array (`names`) to maintain the original correspondence between the data pairs.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, primitive arrays and arrays of objects (like String[]) are distinct data structures. Operating on one array (e.g., sorting `scores` using `Arrays.sort()`) modifies only that array's contents or order. There is no automatic mechanism—the programmer must explicitly implement the logic to swap elements in the `names` array every time the corresponding elements in the `scores` array are swapped to maintain the parallel structure integrity. By only sorting `scores`, the scores are detached from their original names.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output (the top score is paired with the incorrect student name).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that calling Arrays.sort(scores) will automatically keep the names array synchronized with the scores array, or that sorting the scores array alone is sufficient to identify the top student by simply accessing the last index.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student does not understand that Arrays.sort() only sorts the specified array in place. When working with parallel arrays, sorting one array breaks the correspondence between the two arrays. The names and scores that were paired together become separated. After sorting scores in ascending order, the name at index N-1 no longer corresponds to the highest score—only the score value at that index is the highest. The student needs to either: (1) track indices during sorting, (2) use a custom sorting mechanism that swaps both arrays together, or (3) use an array of objects that keeps data together.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output—the program prints the wrong student name paired with the correct highest score, because the name-score correspondence is broken after sorting.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Incorrect Assumption About Finding Maximum Value
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that after sorting an array in ascending order, the last element is always the maximum, and they can directly use that to find the top student. However, they fail to realize that in a parallel array scenario, they must find the index of the maximum score first, then use that same index in the names array.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student confuses the process of finding a maximum value in a single array with managing relationships across multiple arrays. They assume that if scores[N-1] contains the max score after sorting, then names[N-1] must contain the corresponding name. This breaks down because the sorting operation rearranged only the scores array, leaving the names array in its original order.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output—the program outputs the name from the original N-1 position instead of the name of the student who actually has the highest score.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Assuming Parallel Arrays Stay Aligned When Sorting Only One Array
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting the scores array alone (using Arrays.sort(scores)) will somehow keep the names array aligned with the corresponding scores, so that taking the last index from both arrays will give the top student and their highest score.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, each array is an independent data structure. Calling Arrays.sort(scores) only reorders the elements inside the scores array; the names array is completely untouched and remains in its original order. After sorting, scores[i] no longer matches the original names[i] unless the programmer explicitly performs corresponding swaps on both arrays (or uses a combined data structure like a Student object and sorts a single array/list of those). The student's approach—sorting only scores, then using the same index in names and scores—breaks the correspondence between name and score and reflects a misunderstanding of how sorting and parallel arrays interact.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: wrong output (name does not match the highest score)

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that calling `Arrays.sort(scores)` automatically reorganizes the elements in the parallel array, `names`, to maintain the correct correspondence between names and scores, even though the `names` array is not explicitly sorted or manipulated alongside the `scores` array.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, array sorting methods like `Arrays.sort()` operate only on the array they are called on. They do not have knowledge of or influence over parallel data structures used to store related information. When the student sorts only the `scores` array, the original pairing between the score and the corresponding student name is lost, leading to incorrect results after the sort.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting the `scores` array will automatically maintain the correspondence between the `names` and `scores` arrays. They think that after calling `Arrays.sort(scores)`, the elements at the same index in both arrays will still correspond to the same student.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: When working with parallel arrays, sorting one array independently breaks the one-to-one correspondence with the other array. The student fails to understand that `Arrays.sort()` only sorts the target array—it doesn't affect the other array. After sorting only `scores`, the pairing between `names[i]` and `scores[i]` is broken. The name at index 2 is no longer associated with the score at index 2.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output. With input names=[Alice, Bob, Charlie] and scores=[85, 92, 78], the code sorts scores to [78, 85, 92] but names remains [Alice, Bob, Charlie]. The code then outputs 'Top student: Charlie (92)' instead of the correct 'Top student: Bob (92)' because it grabs names[2]='Charlie' and scores[2]=92, which are no longer paired.
